title: Ticket #185: Schedd bloat
description:
A support rust request came in to look at why their schedd was allocating memory until it could no longer do so. They are using the SOAP interface, so I patched a version of 7.0.5 and sent them that for testing. This change did not solve the problem.

I thought about having them use 7.2.1, but it seem the problem still persists there too. It turns out that this problem is not limited to jobs submitted via the SOAP interface, a large number of jobs submitted via condor_submit will result in the same behavior. This has only been tested and confirmed on Windows, but may not be platform specific.

The problem can be reproduced by submitting >1000 or so jobs back to back.
remarks:
2009-Feb-04 18:21:30 by burnett:
I've attached the scripts and submit file that can be used to reproduce the problem. The batch file condor_bloat.bat takes two parameters, first the submit file to use and second, the number of times it should be submitted.

2009-Feb-04 22:43:17 by matt:
Is this only on Windows? I've submitted >>1000 clusters before to linux systems and not had excessive memory use.

2009-Feb-05 15:52:27 by tannenba:
At this point, it looks like it may be specific to Windows.

To clarify, what Ben told me was the schedd's memory working set size, as reported by the task manager, gets very large as the jobs run (to be expected), but then after the jobs are all done and the queue is empty, the working set size is still huge!! Strange. I would expect the image size to grow and not shrink after the jobs are done, but one would expect the working set size to shrink back to normal...

2009-Feb-06 01:25:24 by burnett:
The leak has been fixed. The original fix for the SOAP memory leak was erroneous. This patch I submitted remedies the flaw.

The original soap_copy()+free() pairing was correct; however, further housekeeping was necessary before a the soap structure could be free()’d. The reason for this is that the soap structure itself, internal malloc()'d data only it knew about, necessitating a call to soad_done()--which freed up several internal structures--before freeing the soap structure itself.

2009-Feb-06 08:02:53 by matt:
How does your new commit fix any memory leaks?

Your commit should be reverted... 

commit 181359198572dc949ee228bbb20a8f7f27d2b9e5
Author: Ben Burnett <burnett@cs.wisc.edu>
Date:   Fri Feb 6 00:53:27 2009 -0600

    The original fix for the SOAP memory leak was erroneous.
    This patch remedies the flaw.

    The original soap_copy()+free() pairing was correct; however,
    further housekeeping was necessary before a the soap structure
    could be free()<92>d.  The reason for this is that the soap structure
    itself, was full of memory only it knew about, necessitating
    a call to soad_done()--which freed up several internal structures--
    before freeing the soap structure itself.

diff --git a/src/condor_daemon_core.V6/daemon_core.cpp b/src/condor_daemon_core.
V6/daemon_core.cpp
index fbca911..63aa4b2 100644
--- a/src/condor_daemon_core.V6/daemon_core.cpp
+++ b/src/condor_daemon_core.V6/daemon_core.cpp
@@ -3617,7 +3617,8 @@ int DaemonCore::HandleReq(Stream *insock)
      soap_serve(cursoap);
      soap_destroy(cursoap); // clean up class instances
      soap_end(cursoap); // clean up everything and close socket
-     soap_free(cursoap);
+     soap_done(cursoap); // close master socket and detach environment
+     free(cursoap); // free up
      dprintf(D_ALWAYS, "Completed servicing HTTP request\n");

         // gsoap already closed the socket.  so set the socket in

  free(soap);
